intro: Galium uliginosum subsp. langei, commonly known as the swamp bedstraw, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to wetland habitats in North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, often prostrate stems that root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white to pinkish flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic, and often have a hairy texture. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is an important component of wetland ecosystems.
